text: Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Well, you folks let’s do this, okay? I -- I’m gonna put the prescription into the pharmacy here, and they’re gonna start checking as to how much it’s gonna cost you. You may say that we don’t have a prescription plan or it’s too expensive, and I can’t do it for that reason. It may be that we get through that and the door’s still open for the study because you can afford it and we can get started. Okay? But you guys have to talk about it as a family. You’ve got the paperwork to read. You can go through it, discuss it. You know, okay, this would mean that we’re gonna have to commit to going down to Baltimore every other week this time, do some more bloodwork. These are the things that I worry about. Yeah, we’re all good for that. Okay? Because you’re not on the study until you meet again with us, that your PSA is rising on the enzalutamide Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have to get the enzalutamide started (Pause) Patient: Okay. Okay. Lemme just, so the enzalutamide, the Xtandi, okay. Doctor: That’s all we’re going to start now, and you have to get worse on it to be able to be eligible for the study. (Pause15sec) Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure.

text: Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out. Family Member: Uh Huh. Doctor: I don’t want that sort of trouble. Okay? Family Member: Are, are Have they come, - Is there any chance that they’d come closer to a purification, cure for cancer? Like that chelation therapy that I heard about years ago. Is that something that the insurance companies are willing to look at? Doctor: Hum. No. Nothing, nothing close to primetime yet. Family Member: But it is a, it is an effective treatment, right? Doctor: I’m not sure exactly.

text: Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? text: Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body? Doctor: No it’s just a sign, it’s like a sign like or more aggressiveness. We call it a prognostic factor. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It doesn’t mean that it’s touching something else. Family Member: And do they normally, do you normally just get a sampling of lymph nodes or is there a certain number you see or amount? Doctor: There’s a region that we remove lymph nodes. Family Member: Okay.

text: Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get -- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: a second line hormone versus a second line hormone plus this new PARP drug versus this PARP drug. So, Patient: But, that will be a decision we will make together. Doctor: Yeah, and that’s a coin flip between all those three. Um. That’s kind of a random trial. So, we can talk about that. Um. The immune therapy story is an earlier - it’s still in it’s earlier phases, but people are starting to think, if you have these mutations, you’re making abnormal things on the - in the cell, and that might – and that’s what kind of gets the immune system excited, something that looks weird. And, maybe you would respond better – ‘cuz right now when we give these new immune drugs, they work really well for some cancers Kidney cancer, melanoma, lung cancer. They don’t work very well for prostate cancer in just the general population. So, we’re trying to --- we think they’re good drugs, but we’re trying to figure out what’s the best way to use those. Patient: They might be usable with somebody with the genetic mutation. Doctor: Right. That’s what they’re – we have some kind of preliminary evidence, that’s true. No one’s done a huge study yet to, to prove that. What we were – I told you about this study we’re trying to do which is, we had two men who got one of our testosterone studies, responded, stayed on the drug for about a year, came off the drug, got some other things, and then got an immune therapy trial, with the expectation that the, uh, the immune therapy doesn’t work really well. But, both of those guys had unbelievable response; a ninety-nine percent drop in their PSA, disease disappeared. So, we’re not exactly sure, but what they both had in common was that they got testosterone. So, our, our, one of our trials is looking at that combination. Does the testosterone change the cell surface or whatever? So, we can talk about that, too, but

text: Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But I haven’t, I don’t cure anybody with prostate cancer, so I’m getting frustrated in my career. You know? Is there something I can do that has a chance to cure the disease? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The only thing I could think of, so we’re testing the bone marrow transplant idea is being prostate. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So their immune system has not been exposed to prostate tissue. What if we used a female into a male? Family Member: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
